awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated memristor neural networks for in-situ analysis of intracellular neuronal recordings
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to detect and analyze individual neuron spiking patterns over large areas will have profound impacts on neuroscience and medicine, as it allows the functions of the brain to be directly mapped to underlying neuron activities and enables precise brain disease detection and drug developments. However, although recent advances in neuroprobes such as nanoelectrode arrays make it possible to pick up signals from single neurons, scaling the systems to thousands and possibly millions of neuron sites is not practical due the enormous resources and time required to digitize, store and analyze the vast amount of data. This proposal aims to precisely address these challenges by integrating an artificial neural network on the nanoelectrode array, such that cell signals picked up by the electrodes are directly processed by the artificial neural network, and only the processed, "useful" data need to be amplified and transmitted, allowing real-time analysis with very low power. Undergraduate and graduate students will be trained to obtain state-of-the-art nanotechnology and neuroengineering techniques. Knowledge and techniques developed during research will be incorporated into course materials and other types of publications to allow cross pollination for students among different disciplines and broad dissemination to the general public. 
The proposed new neural recording system will offer unparalleled spatial resolution and processing capabilities, where high density and highly sensitive nanoelectrode arrays are integrated with a memristor-based artificial neural network that allows real time signal processing. By optimizing and utilizing internal dynamic ionic processes in the memristors, the artificial network can be directly driven by the spike trains from biological neurons without amplification or other pre-processing, where responses from the memristor network can be used to analyze temporal patterns in the neuron spikes and to connect detected neuronal activity with functions of the biological networks. The tightly coupled memristor network with the biological network can further allow functions in the biological system to be directly mapped on the electrical system, and potentially lead to future neural prosthesis and augmentation applications. New materials, devices, and networks will be developed, along with new recording and computing strategies that broaden the impact of the proposed project.

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to build efficient memristor networks for high-density and real-time neural signal processing and function mapping. The team hypothesized that the internal dynamics of memristors can allow memristor networks to directly process streaming inputs, including spike signals collected from high-density nanoelectrode arrays without any amplification, digitization or other pre-processing techniques. The ability to utilize device and network dynamics allows the artificial memristor networks to autonomously detect and process the spatio-temporal features in the spike inputs, leading to functions such as neural connectivity mapping and spiking pattern recognition. This approach can lead to integrated neuroprobes that that allow efficient human-machine interface in the future.

 

Five well-defined and tightly integrated tasks have been carried out. Task 1.1 Detect neuron spiking patterns with memristor network using internal dynamics of memristor networks for spiking pattern recognition. Task 1.2: Mapping neuron activity patterns to memristor network to detect connectivity patterns in the biological network and the evolution of such connectivity patterns. Task 2.1 Memristor device optimization to develop devices that require low programming voltage and current such they can be directly stimulated by the sensed spike signals from the nanoelectrode arrays. Task 2.2. Internal time constant control to allow systematic tuning of the internal time constant of the memristor devices for desired applications, and Task 2.3. Memristor network integration to explore larger networks and hierarchical systems for future large-area, high-resolution recording and analysis.

 

 

During the past 4 years, the PI and his students have made significant progress in the proposed tasks, and obtained the following outcomes:

1)     We experimentally verified that reservoir computing systems based on dynamic perovskite halide memristors can directly detect spiking patterns including Tonic, Bursting, Irregular, and Adapting, in real time. We developed memristors with very low switching voltage (< 100 mV) and current (1-100 nA) that can be directly excited by emulated neural signals. Our results verified the concept of internal memristor dynamics to directly process streaming spiking patterns with low latency, high performance and low hardware overhead. This work was reported in Zhu et al. “Memristor networks for real-time neural activity analysis”, Nature Communications, 11, 2439 (2020)  

2)     We showed that spike-timing-dependent plasticity can be natively implemented by the internal dynamics of the memristor device and leads to the successful discovery of temporal correlations between pre- and post-synaptic spikes of simulated neural circuits in an unsupervised fashion. The proposed system demonstrates high classification accuracy under a wide range of parameter settings considering indirect connections, synaptic weights, transmission delays, connection density, etc., and enables the capturing of dynamic connectivity evolutions. This work was reported in Wu et al. “Neural Functional Connectivity Reconstruction with Second‐Order Memristor Network”, Advanced Intelligent Systems, 3, 2000276 (2021) and Wu et al. “Spatiotemporal Spike Pattern Detection with Second-order Memristive Synapses," 2022 IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems (ISCAS), 2022.

3)     Through careful engineering aided by detailed physics-based simulation, we showed that the internal decay constant in 2nd-order memristors can be tuned by inserting a heat-insulation layer and by changing the effective device area. With these techniques, we can natively implement different spike-timing dependent plasticity (STDP) effects in such devices so that the characteristics time constants in the artificial memristor network can be tuned to match those in the connected biological networks. This work was reported in Yoo et al, “Tuning Resistive Switching Behavior by Controlling Internal Ionic Dynamics for Biorealistic Implementation of Synaptic Plasticity”, Advanced Electronic Materials, 8, 2101025 (2022).

4)     We expanded the memristor-based reservoir computing system to hierarchical reservoir structures and columnar learning networks based on pyramidal neurons. Besides common feedforward connections, we expect the lateral and feedback connections in the columnar networks can allow the system to more efficiently learn spatiotemporal features. Additionally, cumulative outputs from multiple columns can allow the system to process data from multiple sensory inputs, resulting in better performance and error tolerance. This work was reported in Moon et al. “Hierarchical architectures in reservoir computing systems”, Neuromorphic Computing and Engineering, 1, 014006 (2021), and Yoo et al. “Columnar Learning Networks for Multisensory Spatiotemporal Learning”, Adv. Intell. Syst., 4: 2200179, (2022).

 

The outcomes have been broadly disseminated to the research community and the general public. The PI and his students have published 7 papers in prestigious journals, and given invited talks at major internal conferences on findings of this project. 3 Ph.D. students have been systematically trained based on funding from NSF. The findings have also been incorporated in a graduate-level course the PIs developed, and shared with the general public through publications, presentations, and online resources. Several new research directions have been established, and hardware and software infrastructure has been developed during the project.  The findings have also inspired several new students who have since become actively engaged in research in related topics.
